body:
> @mkevo Thanks for the contribution! Please let us know in comments or on the dev-list if you have questions about any of @jinmeiliao's comments or anything else.

I'm working on changes, if I have any questions I will ask. Thanks for help! :)

After more investigation I realized some things. 
How it worked before: 
- handleNotification decide when to logout when received notification _jmx.remote.connection.closed_
- logout function get Subject from the current thread and logout it
- in case the current thread is owner of session it will delete all credentials, and other connections will failed

How it works now:
- handleNotifiaction will received when connection is opened and put _connectionId_ and _Subject_ to map.
- when handleNotification received that connection is closed it calls new function with _connectionId_ and _Subject_, so it can logout right user without losing credentials
@mivanac I just merged this to develop. Thank you!
Merged this change in. Thanks for the contribution!

Thanks for the feedback.
> Is there a test that makes sure we didn't change observable behavior from the client? Meaning, is there a test that makes sure size returns the same value before and after this change?

There isn't a test for this right now but I don't think is necessary to add one, basically because the `ClientServerSessionCache.size()` method is just a wrapper for `Region.sizeOnServer()`, which is already tested in several parts of the product. The old behaviour did exactly the same but with more boilerplate, so no changes to what the user sees. I can add an extra test for this if you want, anyway.
Cheers.

> I wanted it to run all the checks though…it didn’t seem to kick them off when I did a draft?

Draft PRs are supposed to kick off the checks. Sometimes you have to make an empty commit to trigger the checks. This can happen even for regular PRs.

> The names for the test methods `invokeXXXXCallbacksSkipInvoke` and `invokeXXXXCallbacksSkipInvoke2` are not helpful to the reader, can you rename them to something more meaningful?.

For the first two new tests, good names might be:

- `invokeTXCallbacksDoesNotInvokeCallbacksIfEventIsNotGenerateCallbacks()`
- `invokeTXCallbacksDoesNotInvokeCallbacksIfPartitionedRegionIsNotInitialized()`

I've tried to glean the important conditions (e.g. IfEventIsNotGenerateCallbacks) from the mock setups, and the important results (e.g. DoesNotInvokeCallbacks) from the assertions. If I've named them wrong, or omitted important conditions or results, adjust the names as necessary.
Closing because this will require significantly more work, and priorities have changed. When we come back to this, it would probably be best to refactor the whole pool.
Need to wait for a major version bump before we can do this.
I will create 2 PRs

@mkevo thanks for the contribution. what's the use case that you are trying to accommodate here? Looks like you are trying to log in using different user on the same thread. Shouldn't the 2nd user wipe out the first user's credentials completely already? I don't think we need to keep the first user around when user logs in the 2nd user.
Merged manually as https://github.com/apache/geode/commit/48030961f82f91360d8c88f19516758ba0d6affe
@Petahhh @jmelchio

Hi @jinmeiliao, in logging method(_IntegratedSecurityService.java_) it remove ThreadContext so new Thread will be added for other user. 
The problem is in logout. At the start it trying to catch subject from currentThread and it is a wrong behavior. Method logout is called every time when it get **JMXConnectionNotification.CLOSED** and it doesn't know what connection is closed and catch current thread and logout user from it. If we logout that user, and after that received one more **JMXConnectionNotification.CLOSED**  it will try again logout user from current thread which is now null. 
With this solution, when connection is closed it will send which user is disconnected and on which thread it is, so logout method will not get it from current thread as it will have this information and know what user from which thread it need to logout.
I don't think so, but I'm willing to defer if the community has more thoughts than I.  Thanks for pointing it out!
Well, this change went over like a lead balloon.
@pivotal-jbarrett @dschneider-pivotal Could you please review this PR?

@jmelchio it does seem simple enough to just use the `CompletableFuture` rather than creating any separate state object for now, and then we just need the map rather than a full manager class.  We probably still need some sort of service registry in order to separate the operation parameters from implementation (since ClientCMS can't have any dependencies on geode-core).  I envision an `exec` or `perform` method similar to our generic CMS `list` method, e.g. takes an OperationRequest input and returns a CompletableFuture of a correlated OperationResult type (for the Java API) or a check URI (for the REST api)

@onichols-pivotal @jinmeiliao @jackw26

@kirklund, could you add more information about using the CompletableFuture class vs. the Future interface?
We discussed using the Future interface and were concerned about its "cancel" method. The concern was that the geode core may not have support for cancelling the long running operation. So the locator could stop waiting for the op to finish but the op itself would still be running. Would you recommend that in that case we implement cancel to throw an unsupported op exception?
I built the code and ran the test. It looked good. I don't know this code space well, so I will leave it to others to review.

@dschneider-pivotal Dale encouraged us to use CompletableFuture for a similar requirement in server startup notification which involves multiple async operations. It's still very much a work-in-progress, but you can check out an early draft of our code (with bugs) in #3799 (you can view it there even if we close the draft PR). We found a [great YouTube video by Angelika Langer that includes some great coverage on CompletableFuture](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q_0_1mKTlnY) that I recommend checking out.

Edit: CompletableFuture is basically used to represent async operations. It implements both the Future and CompletionStage interfaces. It provides ways to aggregate multiple async operations (multiple CompletableFutures) as one CompletableFuture. It also provides ways to submit Runnables that will fire when the async operation completes.

I don't know enough about cancel or why you need to prevent it. I guess if you evaluate CompletableFuture and determine it won't work because of how or if it supports cancellation, then I'll ultimately approve not using it. I would think that Cache close or JVM shutdown would require cancellation support. Or you could maybe subclass CompletableFuture to override the cancel methods.

Edit: Good articles with better info on CompleteableFutures than I can write:
- [Write Clean Asynchronous Code With CompletableFuture Java-8](https://nirajsonawane.github.io/2019/01/27/Write-Clean-asynchronous-code-with-CompletableFuture-Java-8/)
- [Java 8: Definitive guide to CompletableFuture](https://www.nurkiewicz.com/2013/05/java-8-definitive-guide-to.html)
- [Java 8: Writing asynchronous code with CompletableFuture](https://www.deadcoderising.com/java8-writing-asynchronous-code-with-completablefuture/)
- [Guide To CompletableFuture](https://www.baeldung.com/java-completablefuture)

> We discussed using the Future interface…
Do you mean that you discussed using `CompletableFuture`?

> … and were concerned about its "cancel" method. The concern was that the geode core may not have support for cancelling the long running operation. So the locator could stop waiting for the op to finish but the op itself would still be running. Would you recommend that in that case we implement cancel to throw an unsupported op exception?

The `cancel()` method is a bit of a wart in `CompletableFuture`, which has the method only because it inherits it from `Future`. As the `CompletableFuture` javadoc says: "Method `cancel` has the same effect as `completeExceptionally(new CancellationException())`." That is, it marks the `CompletableFuture` as completed with a cancellation exception, and does nothing else. In particular: It does not actually cancel the task itself. Indeed, it has absolutely no effect on the task.

This behavior seems likely to surprise callers. So if we really don't want to cancel the task, then override `cancel()` to throw unsupported op.

@alb3rtobr @jujoramos If you need to use the `TemporaryFolder` from multiple DUnit JVMs then you can use the subclass `SerializableTemporaryFolder`. It'll serialize fine and is then usable from any JVM.

> @alb3rtobr @jujoramos If you need to use the `TemporaryFolder` from multiple DUnit JVMs then you can use the subclass `SerializableTemporaryFolder`. It'll serialize fine and is then usable from any JVM.

Do you think its needed in these tests? The folder is used to receive the exported logs zip files.

@alb3rtobr I honestly don't know, but it doesn't hurt anything to change it to `SerializableTemporaryFolder`. You could just always use the `Serializable` and `Shareable` forms of any junit rules (if they exist) in dunit/distributed tests just in case.

> I think it might be better to simply not rely in the case of these cancel exceptions - or maybe wait to process the member departure on the sending side of this PrepareNewPersistent...Message?
> 
> You added some retries in the case of this exception, but that looks like it's only for when we are creating the bucket for the very first time? What about when we are recovering the bucket from disk? We don't want that operation to fail if one of our peers is shutting down at the time we are recovering - and I don't think that has a retry.

You are right, retry for recovering case only occurs in getFromOne during GII. We do need to handle the case when recovering without GII.
@jmelchio

@albertogpz @agingade I tried to understand the retry logic after the refactor and I just can't. I understand wanting to refactor this function execution code because it is not very readable and testable but I am not sure this refactor achieves that. There is pretty significant failure somewhere in here that causes the single hop function with filters to re-execute every time. There is an opportunity for an integration or dunit test that validates that a single hop is not re-invoked as multi hop without a failure event.

I suggest we revert this refactor and try again. Benchmarks have been red for a week now while we tried to track down the root cause.

Regarding the usage of Internal API, below is the list of classes for which the task couldn't be achieved and the actual reasons:
- `AbstractCache`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `AbstractSessionAttributes`: belongs to an internal package, it can use internal classes.
- `Banner`: no replacement for `GemFireVersion` in public packages.
- `CreateRegionFunction`: internal function that creates an internal region dealing with internal mechanisms, no replacements in public packages.
- `DeltaEvent`: belongs to an internal package, it can use internal classes.
- `DeltaSession`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `DeltaSessionManager`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `DeltaSessionStatistics`: belongs to an internal package, it can use internal classes.
- `GatewayDeltaCreateEvent`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `GatewayDeltaEventApplicationCacheListener`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `GatewayDeltaForwarderCacheListener`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `GemfireSessionManager`: belongs to an internal package, it can use internal classes.
- `Installer`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `RegionHelper`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `BootstrappingFunctionTest`: no replacements for used API in public classes.
- `ClientServerSessionCacheDUnitTest`: no replacements for used API in public classes.

Hey @mcmellawatt ,

Thanks for reviewing this, guess it wasn't an easy task due to the amount of files changed... :sweat_smile:. Regarding the Tomcat tests in the `org.apache.geode.session.tests` package, they should be included as part of CI execution under the `:geode-assembly:distributedTest` task:

```
./gradlewStrict -PcompileJVM=/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64 -PcompileJVMVer=8 -PtestJVM=/usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64 -PtestJVMVer=11 -PparallelDunit -PdunitDockerUser=geode -PdunitDockerImage=$(docker images --format '{{.Repository}}:{{.Tag}}') -PdunitParallelForks=24 --parallel --console=plain --no-daemon -x javadoc -x spotlessCheck -x rat distributedTest
```

We should be fine to merge this PR once the last CI finishes (assuming everything's green):
Cheers.

@jujoramos @boglesby ConnectionStatsTest already exists, but I have started reviewing the existing tests. I will be uploading the changes in separated commits, I think its better for review.

I think I would have the same concern that doing it in BucketRegion.virtualPut would have the same concurrency issues. AbstractRegionMap has the code that can do this atomically once based on the state of the RegionEntry. It syncs the RegionEntry. It already has to look up or create the RegionEntry and it does it in a thread safe way.

> Can you explain why the RegionPerfStats is now keeping a local copy of the entry count? Unless there is a non-stats use for this counter then it should just be kept by stats/meters and not yet another thing.

Here's our thinking:
- Micrometer gauges do not accumulate values. They only fetch values from some source.
- We didn't want to invent a new meter type for this use case… yet. We may revisit this decision in the future as we get more experience linking Geode gauges to Micrometer gauges. (If we did create a new "cumulative gauge" meter type, that would also be "yet another thing.")
- Currently Geode accumulates these increments and decrements only in stats. There is no other available source for this accumulated value.
- We didn't want to configure the meter to fetch from the stat, because that would increase our dependence on stats. Given that we want to deprecate/remove stats eventually, we would eventually have to create some non-stat place to accumulate the increments and decrements. We chose to do that work now instead of deferring it until later.
- So we added a new field to accumulate the increments and decrements, and configured the meter and the stat to get their values from that.
This was also done in PR #3824, see https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3824/files#diff-ac14f73a76d33d5c50aca5669b4bbed6
